item.title: Methodology
item.author: Z3KAIx0
item.content:
How Hackers Plan and Execute Attacks: A Full Methodology Guide

Introduction

Hackers donâ€™t just break into systems randomly. There is a structured plan, step-by-step, to find weak spots and gain access. Whether itâ€™s to test security or cause harm, understanding this methodology is important for protecting against attacks. ğŸ›¡ï¸

1. Reconnaissance: Gathering Information ğŸ”

The first stage of hacking is called reconnaissance, where hackers gather as much information ğŸ¤¤ as possible about their target. This phase is like spyingâ€”the hacker learns everything they can without anyone noticing. The more they know, the easier it is to find vulnerabilities later on. Hackers will often search the web for publicly available information, such as contact details, addresses, and software used by the target. They might look at social media to discover employee names, roles, and technologies the company uses. The hacker uses tools to gather hidden data, like emails, subdomains, or server details.

Tools Used in Reconnaissance:

  • Google Dorking: Hackers use advanced Google search techniques to find sensitive information that shouldnâ€™t be publicly available. ğŸ§
  • theHarvester: This tool collects emails, subdomains, and domain info from public sources, such as search engines and social media. ğŸ“§
  • Maltego: A tool for visualizing relationships between people, organizations, and domains. ğŸŒ
  • Shodan: A search engine for finding Internet of Things (IoT) devices connected to the internet, like cameras or servers. ğŸ“¡
  • Recon-ng: A web reconnaissance tool that automates the process of gathering information. ğŸ–¥ï¸

2. Scanning and Enumeration: Looking for Open Doors ğŸšª

After gathering information, hackers start looking for open doorsâ€”ways to enter the target system. This phase involves scanning the targetâ€™s network and looking for vulnerabilities or services that can be exploited. Hackers scan the targetâ€™s system for open ports (like doors) and vulnerable services that can be attacked. They use enumeration to collect more detailed information, such as usernames or system configurations.

Tools Used in Scanning and Enumeration:

  • Nmap: A popular tool for scanning networks to find open ports and services. ğŸ”
  • Nikto: Scans web servers for vulnerabilities, such as outdated software or misconfigurations. ğŸŒ
  • OpenVAS: A vulnerability scanner that helps find weaknesses in systems. ğŸ”
  • Dirb / Dirbuster: Tools used to discover hidden directories or files on a website. ğŸ—‚ï¸
  • Masscan: A faster version of Nmap used to scan large networks. âš¡
  • ffuf: A fast web fuzzer used to discover hidden files and directories on websites. ğŸ”

3. Gaining Access: Breaking In ğŸ”“

Once the hacker has found a weakness, itâ€™s time to break in. The goal of this phase is to exploit vulnerabilities and gain control of the system, whether by using an exploit, social engineering, or password cracking. Hackers use exploits to take advantage of weaknesses in the system. They may use social engineering to trick employees into revealing passwords or personal information. If the system is password-protected, hackers might use brute-force tools to guess the correct password.

Tools Used in Gaining Access:

  • Metasploit Framework: A powerful tool that contains exploits to break into systems by targeting known vulnerabilities. âš™ï¸
  • SQLmap: Used to exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities in websites and gain access to databases. ğŸ’¾
  • Hydra: A password-cracking tool that tests multiple combinations to guess login credentials. ğŸ”‘
  • John the Ripper: Another password-cracking tool, mainly used to decode hashed passwords. ğŸ”“
  • MSFvenom: Used to create malicious payloads that help hackers gain control once theyâ€™ve entered a system. ğŸ’£

4. Maintaining Access: Staying Inside ğŸ› ï¸

What is it?

Once the hacker has broken into the system, the next step is to maintain access so they can return later if needed. This is done by installing backdoors, creating hidden accounts, or using malware to establish persistent access.

How does a hacker do it?

Hackers may create backdoors that allow them to access the system later, even if the original vulnerability is fixed. They might install remote access tools (RATs) or malware to make sure they can control the system whenever they want.

Tools Used in Maintaining Access:

  • Netcat: A tool used to create backdoors, allowing hackers to maintain remote access. ğŸŒ
  • Meterpreter: A tool for post-exploitation, giving hackers full control over the system. ğŸ®
  • Empire: A framework for maintaining access and controlling the system remotely. ğŸŒ
  • RATs (Remote Access Trojans): Malicious software that gives hackers full control over the system. ğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸

5. Covering Tracks: Hiding Evidence ğŸ•¶ï¸

What is it?

The final phase of the attack involves covering tracks to avoid detection. Hackers do this by erasing logs, hiding evidence, and making it appear like they were never there.

How does a hacker do it?

Hackers will delete logs that record system activities to remove traces of their actions. They may use rootkits to hide their presence or change file timestamps to make it look like they didnâ€™t access certain files. The goal is to erase all evidence of the attack so that the target doesnâ€™t realize theyâ€™ve been compromised.

Tools Used in Covering Tracks:

  • CCleaner: A tool used to clear system logs and browsing history. ğŸ§¹(miss used by hackers )
  • Rootkits: Malicious tools used to hide evidence of a hack or maintain access without detection. ğŸ›¡ï¸
  • LogCleaner: A tool to edit or delete logs, hiding any traces of the hackerâ€™s activity. ğŸ“
  • Timestomp: A tool that changes file timestamps, making it look like the hacker wasnâ€™t there. ğŸ•°ï¸

Conclusion

Hacking isnâ€™t random or chaoticâ€”itâ€™s a structured, methodical process. Hackers follow a clear path, from gathering information and scanning for vulnerabilities to maintaining access and covering their tracks. Understanding these steps is crucial for defending against attacks and strengthening cybersecurity. Whether youâ€™re an ethical hacker or simply interested in how attacks work, knowledge of these phases is the first step in protecting systems and data from intruders. ğŸš€

‘My Cybersecurity Journey: Kicking Off with HTB CPTS Certification’

Hey there! This is my first blog post, and Iâ€™m officially divingğŸ¤¿ into the world of cybersecurityâ€”with the Hack The Box (CPTS) certification as my first step.

Why HTB CPTS?

Honestly? Itâ€™s only $210, and the certificate design is cool as f***(Design OPğŸ™ƒ). Hack The Box gives you hands-on experience in a controlled environment where you can test real-world hacking techniques. Itâ€™s not just about theoryâ€”it’s about actually doing.Hacking ainâ€™t about ticking boxes âœ… â€” itâ€™s about figuring stuff out like a boss ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚

Say what you want, but all the HTB certs look crazy cool ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥

Certification Roadmap

Iâ€™m not picking certs randomlyâ€”these things cost ğŸ’°, and Iâ€™ve still got OSCP on my radar. So yeah, it is what it is ğŸ™ƒ. If u want cybersecurity certification roadmap (means u does’t know which cert to take first after that which )its down here ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡

ğŸ”— Paul Jerimy’s Security Certification Roadmap

This roadmap is a visual guide that maps out various cybersecurity certifications. If you’re looking for a certification path in any fieldâ€”offensive security, risk management, networking, etc.â€”everything’s there.

Fun Fact ğŸ‘‰ After visiting that website, I got to know about OSEE ğŸ˜³ OSEE

*This screenshot showing how i will gooooo ...*

My Study Plan

This is nothing fancyâ€”just how I broke down all the CPTS topics into parts that make sense for meâ€”helps me stay on track and not feel overwhelmed.

Part 1: Getting Started

Topic What It Means
Penetration Testing Basics This is where you learn the fundamentals of hacking. You need to understand the mindset behind penetration testingâ€”how to approach testing systems for vulnerabilities and how hackers exploit them for ethical reasons.
Using Nmap to Find Computers Nmap is your go-to tool for scanning networks. It helps you identify live hosts, open ports, and services on a network, giving you a blueprint of what you’re dealing with.

Part 2: Finding Information

Topic What It Means
Footprinting This is the first step in gathering information about a target. It involves looking up domain names, email addresses, social media profiles, and public databases to gather as much information as possible.
Info from Websites By scraping or manually collecting data from a targetâ€™s website, you can uncover clues about their internal network, technologies they use, and even hidden vulnerabilities.

Part 3: Finding Weaknesses & Exploiting Them

Topic What It Means
Finding Weaknesses Vulnerability scanning is all about identifying flaws in a system that can be exploited. This involves using automated tools and manual techniques to find weaknesses in a system’s defenses.
Transferring Files When conducting a penetration test, transferring files like payloads and scripts between systems is necessary. This can be done through different methods like HTTP, FTP, or SMB.
Shells & Payloads After finding vulnerabilities, the next step is to establish a shell or payload that gives you control over the system. Tools like Netcat or Metasploit make this process easier.

Part 4: Hacking Services & Passwords

Topic What It Means
Using Metasploit Metasploit is one of the most powerful tools in a penetration testerâ€™s arsenal. It helps automate the exploitation of vulnerabilities, making the process quicker and more efficient.
Guessing Passwords Brute-forcing passwords is a classic attack. Tools like Hydra or Burp Suite can help automate this process by testing common passwords or dictionary-based attacks.
Breaking into Services Services like SSH, FTP, or RDP are often the targets of brute-force or known-vulnerability attacks. By compromising these services, you can gain access to a system.

Part 5: Hacking Websites

Topic What It Means
Attacking Websites with Ffuf Ffuf is a fast web fuzzer used to discover hidden directories, files, or other resources on a website that might be vulnerable to attack.
SQL Injection SQL Injection is one of the oldest but still effective attacks on websites. By manipulating database queries, attackers can retrieve sensitive information from a database.
SQLMap SQLMap automates the process of exploiting SQL injection flaws. Itâ€™s a powerful tool for anyone who needs to perform database-based attacks.
Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) XSS attacks allow attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by others. This is a common attack method for stealing user credentials or session tokens.
File Attacks Uploading malicious files (like web shells) to a server is another way to compromise a site. Once the file is executed, you can gain access to the system.
Command Injection Command injection attacks occur when a web application executes system commands from user input. By manipulating this input, you can execute arbitrary commands on the server.

Part 6: Gaining Control

Topic What It Means
Linux Privilege Escalation This is about gaining higher-level access on Linux systems. Common techniques involve exploiting misconfigurations or using local exploits.
Windows Privilege Escalation Privilege escalation on Windows systems often involves exploiting vulnerable services or insecure permissions to gain admin-level access.
Pivoting & Port Forwarding After compromising a system, you may need to pivot to other systems on the network. Port forwarding lets you access systems hidden behind firewalls or NATs.

Part 7: Writing Reports & Big Targets

Topic What It Means
Writing Reports A major part of penetration testing is documenting your findings. This involves creating detailed reports of vulnerabilities found and suggesting mitigation strategies.
Hacking Big Networks Penetration testing isnâ€™t just for small systems. Youâ€™ll need to know how to assess large enterprise networks, dealing with things like Active Directory, firewalls, and other complex security infrastructure.

What’s Next?

So far, played a few beginner boxes on HTB, and itâ€™s realy fun !! ( until or unless u get it ğŸ˜‚ ). The process is been all about scanning, finding weak spots, and exploiting them. THEN BOOM ğŸ’¥

Each challenge teaches something new, and i would like to dive deeper. Once I pass HTB CPTS, Iâ€™ll move on to CBBH, PNPT (maybe), and eventually OSCP. Not sure how i will go but its going to start with CPTS and not end with OSCP because lets decide what to do after OSCP ğŸ˜„

Feel free to follow along with my journey, drop a comment if you have any tips, or letâ€™s discuss whatâ€™s working for you!
